Kevin O'Sullivan wrote:

>  > To me, one of the benefits of tests is that they help me to spot design
>  > problems early. Whenever I find it difficult to write a test for a 
> method,
> I
>  > ask myself whether it's the method's fault.
> 
>     As a newbie to junit I'm still trying to understand how to judge if when
> its 'difficult' to write a test for a method. My question was sparked
> because I was in what I would call a laborous position - multiple code paths
> so multiple test cases. I had 30 test cases for one method, amounting to 300
> lines of code. Is this tedious or difficult. In JUnit world, does tedious ==
> difficult?

I think "tedious == difficult" answers false, so tedium is not as strong 
a warning signal as difficulty; however it /is/ a warning signal.

If you want to learn how to make those judgments, then I believe you 
have to practice. Presumably your method is structured like this.

bigMethod:
     someCode
     if (condition)
         truePart
     else
         falsePart
     end
     moreCode
end

In other words, let's say there's a top-level "if" statement.

So make bigMethod look exactly like the above. Extract everything else 
into methods. Now, can you test someCode, truePart, falsePart and 
moreCode on their own? If not, apply the same refactoring again, and 
again, and again... eventually you'll see how you could fix the testing 
tedium with refactoring.

If your testing tedium is due to wanting to run the same test with 100 
different sets of data, you need better tests (Parameterized Test Case). 
If your testing tedium is due to high cyclomatic complexity, you need 
better production code (refactor, extract method, move method, and so on).

Take care.
